SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which detail from Passage 1 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the idea that worshipping two gods could “lead to trouble”?

A.Choice: “It was for Athena that Athens was named.”

B.Choice: “Poseidon, god of the seas, thought he should protect the village.”

C.Choice: “Greek gods and goddesses were not good at sharing.”

D.Choice: “Both Poseidon and Athena would give the citizens of the town a gift.”

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: Why is paragraph 2 of Passage 1 important to the structure of the passage?

A.Choice: It contrasts two main characters.

B.Choice: It provides the turning point of the story.

C.Choice: It describes the main setting of the story.

D.Choice: It sets up the idea that there will be a problem.

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
In Passage 1, what is the 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 important difference between Athena's and Poseidon's gifts?

A.Choice: The people liked Athena's gift right away but did not understand Poseidon's gift.

B.Choice: Athena wanted to help the people, while Poseidon wanted to impress the gods.

C.Choice: Athena's gift had many uses, while Poseidon's did not.

D.Choice: The people needed olive trees but not water.

Content: Which detail 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “Poseidon thought and thought about what to give.”

B.Choice: “Water was extremely important to the people.”

C.Choice: “They cheered and ran to drink from the spring.”

D.Choice: “The tree would also provide wood for fires.”

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: In Passage 2, which detail 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explains why Arachne believed she was as talented a weaver as Athena?

A.Choice: “A very long time ago, there was a young woman who loved to weave.”

B.Choice: “The more that people complimented her, the prouder she became.”

C.Choice: “And with that she showed off her latest project.”

D.Choice: “Soon people were whispering to Athena about Arachne's work.”

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: In Passage 2, what is a 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 difference between Arachne and Athena?

A.Choice: Arachne works hard, while Athena is lazy.

B.Choice: Arachne is selfish, but Athena is generous.

C.Choice: Arachne has talent, but Athena has the help of the gods.

D.Choice: Arachne has been weaving for years, while Athena has just learned.

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described.
Content: Based on both passages, which word 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes Athena?

A.Choice: confident

B.Choice: gentle

C.Choice: honest

D.Choice: loyal

Topics: Reading Literature - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast stories in the same genre (e.g., mysteries and adventure stories) on their approaches to similar themes and topics.
Content: What is Athena's motivation for starting the contests in 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages?

A.Choice: She wants to prove something.

B.Choice: She hopes to embarrass someone.

C.Choice: She wants to show her kindness.

D.Choice: She thinks she deserves something.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative language such as metaphors and similes.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 1.
:box:And now here it is, m͟a͟j͟e͟s͟t͟i͟c and bigger than I'd ever imagined.
What does the word m͟a͟j͟e͟s͟t͟i͟c mean as it is used in the paragraph?

A.Choice: difficult

B.Choice: frightening

C.Choice: grand

D.Choice: imagined

SubTopics: Explain how a series of chapters, scenes, or stanzas fits together to provide the overall structure of a particular story, drama, or poem.
Content: How is paragraph 14 important to the structure of the passage?

A.Choice: It describes a change in the setting of the story.

B.Choice: It shows a change in the character's attitude.

C.Choice: It describes a turning point in the plot.

D.Choice: It introduces a new idea.

SubTopics: Describe how a narrator's or speaker's point of view influences how events are described.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How does the point of view 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 affect the reader's understanding of the story?

A.Choice: It shows how Donita feels about having to spend spring break in Washington, D.C.

B.Choice: It explains why Donita keeps a photo album of her grandparents' photos.

C.Choice: It shows how Donita's mother and father feel about being at the Capitol.

D.Choice: It explains why Donita's grandparents enjoyed working in the Capitol.

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “My parents talked nonstop about Washington, D.C., and how much fun we were going to have.”

B.Choice: “Learning during my spring break—just what I wanted to do!”

C.Choice: “'They thought it was important,' my dad said.”

D.Choice: “I was wondering why she had packed that ratty old thing.”

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which detail 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 shows that Donita values her trip?

A.Choice: “Just watching them makes my knees shake.”

B.Choice: “It's strange and magical to be viewing these monuments from the very same spots my grandparents did, ages ago.”

C.Choice: “We run up the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, not an easy feat given that my legs burn from all of our walking.”

D.Choice: “We debate what his expression means.”

SubTopics: Compare and contrast two or more characters, settings, or events in a story or drama, drawing on specific details in the text (e.g., how characters interact).
Content: How are the two 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡 settings in the passage different?

A.Choice: One is with Donita's grandparents and the other is with Donita's parents.

B.Choice: One is in Donita's house and the other is Washington, D.C.

C.Choice: One is in the Metro station and the other is at a monument.

D.Choice: One is inside a building and the other is outside.

SubTopics: Determine a theme of a story, drama, or poem from details in the text, including how characters in a story or drama respond to challenges or how the speaker in a poem reflects upon a topic; summarize the text.
Content: Which choice  𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 states the message of the passage?

A.Choice: Things do not always turn out as expected.

B.Choice: It is fun to find out what people's jobs are.

C.Choice: Family is the most important thing in life.

D.Choice: Vacations should be used for learning.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: In Passage 1, the author includes the detail about the gorilla Koko to support what point?

A.Choice: Scientists think they have seen apes laugh.

B.Choice: Scientists did not know apes could use tools.

C.Choice: Apes use their expressive faces to communicate.

D.Choice: Apes have more advanced brains than some other animals.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Based on Passage 1, what is 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 true about the relationships among apes?

A.Choice: Apes speak to each other with sign language.

B.Choice: Apes prefer to live in large family structures.

C.Choice: Apes form strong ties to each other.

D.Choice: Apes only trust other apes.

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “Perhaps the most famous of these apes is Koko.”

B.Choice: “Their babies stay with them for a long time.”

C.Choice: “Big families of gorillas are known as harems.”

D.Choice: “Apes express their thoughts and feelings by hooting.”

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of general academic and domain-specific words and phrases in a text relevant to a grade 5 topic or subject area.
Content: Read this sentence from paragraph 2 of Passage 2.
:box:This was a g͟r͟o͟u͟n͟d͟b͟r͟e͟a͟k͟i͟n͟g discovery, since until that point scientists did not think that animals, including primates, could use tools.
As used in the paragraph, the word g͟r͟o͟u͟n͟d͟b͟r͟e͟a͟k͟i͟n͟g means the discovery was

A.Choice: original and exciting.

B.Choice: strange and confusing.

C.Choice: creative and difficult.

D.Choice: sudden and surprising.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Explain how an author uses reasons and evidence to support particular points in a text, identifying which reasons and evidence support which point(s).
Content: What information from Passage 2 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 shows that Galdikas had a difficult job? Select 𝗧𝗪𝗢 answers.

A.Choice: Orangutans like to keep to themselves.

B.Choice: Orangutans are in danger of losing their homes.

C.Choice: She made valuable observations about orangutans.

D.Choice: Her studies found that orangutans enjoy many foods.

E.Choice: She spent many years trying to get the orangutans to trust her.

SubTopics: Quote accurately from a text when explaining what the text says explicitly and when drawing inferences from the text.
Content: Which conclusion is 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supported by information in Passage 2?

A.Choice: Gorillas used to be aggressive in the wild.

B.Choice: Mother apes are the main caretakers of baby apes.

C.Choice: Apes are very private animals that hide in the jungle.

D.Choice: The scientists became emotionally attached to their subjects.

Topics: Reading Information - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Integrate information from several texts on the same topic in order to write or speak about the subject knowledgeably.
Content: Based on both passages, which choice 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 explains how knowledge about apes has been gained?

A.Choice: from teaching apes to use sticks

B.Choice: from taking part in ape grooming

C.Choice: from the in-person work of experts

D.Choice: from the study of the brains of apes

SubTopics: Analyze multiple accounts of the same event or topic, noting important similarities and differences in the point of view they represent.
Content: With which statement would the authors of 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 𝗟𝗜𝗞𝗘𝗟𝗬 agree?

A.Choice: It's important to protect apes from the threat of habitat loss.

B.Choice: Apes should be taught skills such as sign language and fishing.

C.Choice: Scientists go to great risks to learn about apes.

D.Choice: Research of apes should be limited to zoos.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How does the writer introduce the events of the story?

A.Choice: by showing Joshua's excitement about the garden

B.Choice: by explaining the best place to plant Joshua's garden

C.Choice: by telling about ways Joshua and his father are different

D.Choice: by describing the activities Joshua and his father like best

Content: Which detail from the story 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “Joshua sprinted to the window and peered down at the garden”

B.Choice: “They planned to make pizza with the vegetables”

C.Choice: “Joshua wasn't sure if Dad was right”

D.Choice: “They decided to plant the garden in the backyard”

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: The writer is trying to decide whether sentence 6 belongs in the story. Should the writer keep sentence 6?

A.Choice: Yes, because it is an important part of what Joshua learns about growing healthy plants.

B.Choice: Yes, because it provides descriptive details to help the reader imagine Joshua's experience.

C.Choice: No, because it repeats information that the reader already knows.

D.Choice: No, because it has few details about the type of plants Joshua wants to grow.

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:7. Joshua usually preferred cheese pizza, but Dad said Joshua would change his mind once he tasted vegetables and spices h͟e͟ ͟c͟o͟u͟l͟d͟ ͟h͟a͟v͟e͟ ͟g͟r͟o͟w͟n͟ ͟h͟i͟m͟s͟e͟l͟f.
How should the underlined words in sentence 7 be changed?

A.Choice: he had grown himself

B.Choice: he had to have grown himself

C.Choice: he might have been growing himself

D.Choice: he would have been growing himself

SubTopics: Demonstrate understanding of figurative language, word relationships, and nuances in word meanings.
Content: What does Dad mean when he says “This will open the door to a new experience” in sentence 8?

A.Choice: Joshua will open a pizza business.

B.Choice: Spending time outdoors will be good for Joshua.

C.Choice: Joshua may change his mind about eating vegetables.

D.Choice: Learning to make vegetable pizza will be a challenge for Joshua.

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟭𝟰. But before long, t͟h͟e͟ ͟v͟e͟g͟e͟t͟a͟b͟l͟e͟s͟ ͟s͟t͟a͟r͟t͟e͟d͟ ͟t͟o͟ ͟g͟r͟o͟w͟.
In sentence 14, the writer wants to describe what Joshua sees. Which change to the underlined words would most appeal to the reader's senses?

A.Choice: some small, growing leaves were visible

B.Choice: Joshua noticed that something looked different

C.Choice: Joshua beamed when he saw the seeds were growing

D.Choice: tiny, tender green sprouts began to poke out of the soil

SubTopics: Write narratives to develop real or imagined experiences or events using effective technique, descriptive details, and clear event sequences.
Content: Read this sentence.
:box:𝟏𝟓. The seedlings were ready to plant.
Which words should be added to the beginning of sentence 15 to 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 clearly signal the order of events in the story?

A.Choice: Before then,

B.Choice: At the same time,

C.Choice: Some minutes later,

D.Choice: After several weeks,

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: :ibox:𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How does the writer establish the idea that dogs are capable of learning?

A.Choice: by posing a question about dogs to the reader

B.Choice: by explaining which breeds can be trained successfully

C.Choice: by describing research that shows dogs may be able to count

D.Choice: by contrasting the behavior of the reader's dog with its ancestors

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer above?

A.Choice: “Have you ever wondered just how much your dog understands?”

B.Choice: “Researchers say the length of time the dog stares at the single treat indicates the dog knows one treat is missing.”

C.Choice: “the ability to count may have been important to the dog's ancestors, which needed to keep track of their pups.”

D.Choice: “all dogs are capable of learning.”

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: How should the underlined words in sentence 4 be changed to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 connect the writer's ideas?

A.Choice: Especially

B.Choice: For instance

C.Choice: Furthermore

D.Choice: On the other hand

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: How should the underlined portion of sentence 11 be changed to 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 connect the writer's ideas?

A.Choice: Not only can dogs count

B.Choice: Because dogs can count

C.Choice: Even though dogs can count

D.Choice: Especially since dogs can count

SubTopics: Write informative/explanatory texts to examine a topic and convey ideas and information clearly.
Content: Which change to sentence 12 would make the sentence 𝗠𝗢𝗦𝗧 precise?

A.Choice: Some people have taught their dogs over 150 words.

B.Choice: It is believed that dogs can learn the names of many toys with proper training.

C.Choice: Dog owners argue that certain breeds of dogs are smarter than others, and some cannot be trained.

D.Choice: Researchers say most dogs can learn more than 150 words, but some learn many more if they are trained properly.

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: How should the underlined word in sentence 15 be spelled?

A.Choice: NO CHANGE

B.Choice: inteligense

C.Choice: intelligence

D.Choice: intellagence

SubTopics: Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Content: How should sentence 17 be changed?

A.Choice: The more a dog was trained, the more it learns.

B.Choice: The more a dog is trained, the more it will learn.

C.Choice: The more a dog will be trained, the more it learned.

D.Choice: The more a dog would have been trained, the more it learns.

SubTopics: Write opinion pieces on topics or texts, supporting a point of view with reasons and information.
Content: Now read the writing task and draft a response. As you write, think about what makes your writing the best it can be.
problems/NMG5E/media/33a.jpg

Your school will be hosting a Rocketeer Academy program presented by educators from the New Mexico Museum of Space History. Your teacher is asking students to give their opinion about which program they would like to have come to your school: #1 Portable Planetarium, #2 The Awful Truth about Zero Gravity, or #3 Ozobots.

You have just read an article about the study of space and a web page of the New Mexico Museum of Space History that describes three Rocketeer Academy programs.

Write a letter to your teacher giving your opinion about which program you want to participate in and why. Use details from what you have read, along with your own interests and experiences, to write your opinion letter.

:ibox:Today you will be writing an opinion text. When you write an opinion, you

• tell others your opinion about a topic.
• gather and present reasons for your opinion.
• use specific facts, examples, and details to support those reasons.

After you have read the passages, and before you begin writing, think about

• what ideas in the passages you read lead you to your opinion about which program you would choose.
• what you already know about the topic that supports your opinion.
• how you might respond to ideas that support a different opinion.

Now write your response in the space provided.
